segment.source: Create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with smooth animations, high frame rate, and high-performance media capture and playback.
segment.target: Create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with smooth animations, high frame rate, and high-performance media capture and playback.

segment.source: Make animations smooth
segment.target: Make animations smooth

segment.source: A key aspect of UWP apps is smooth interactions.
segment.target: A key aspect of UWP apps is smooth interactions.

segment.source: This includes touch manipulations that "stick to your finger," smooth transitions and animations, and small motions that provide input feedback.
segment.target: This includes touch manipulations that "stick to your finger," smooth transitions and animations, and small motions that provide input feedback.

segment.source: In the XAML framework there is a thread called the composition thread that is dedicated to the composition and animation of an app’s visual elements.
segment.target: In the XAML framework there is a thread called the composition thread that is dedicated to the composition and animation of an app’s visual elements.

segment.source: Because the composition thread is separate from UI thread (the thread that runs framework and developer code), apps can achieve a consistent frame rate and smooth animations regardless of complicated layout passes or extended calculations.
segment.target: Because the composition thread is separate from UI thread (the thread that runs framework and developer code), apps can achieve a consistent frame rate and smooth animations regardless of complicated layout passes or extended calculations.

segment.source: This section shows how to use the composition thread to keep an app’s animations buttery smooth.
segment.target: This section shows how to use the composition thread to keep an app’s animations buttery smooth.

segment.source: For more info about animations, see Animations overview.
segment.target: For more info about animations, see Animations overview.

segment.source: To learn about increasing an app’s responsiveness while performing intensive computations, see Keep the UI thread responsive.
segment.target: To learn about increasing an app’s responsiveness while performing intensive computations, see Keep the UI thread responsive.

segment.source: Use independent instead of dependent animations
segment.target: Use independent instead of dependent animations

segment.source: Independent animations can be calculated from beginning to end at the time of creation because changes to the property being animated don't affect rest of the objects in a scene.
segment.target: Independent animations can be calculated from beginning to end at the time of creation because changes to the property being animated don't affect rest of the objects in a scene.

segment.source: Independent animations can therefore run on the composition thread instead of the UI thread.
segment.target: Independent animations can therefore run on the composition thread instead of the UI thread.

segment.source: This guarantees that they remain smooth because the composition thread is updated at a consistent cadence.
segment.target: This guarantees that they remain smooth because the composition thread is updated at a consistent cadence.

segment.source: Don't animate a WebView or MediaElement
segment.target: Don't animate a WebView or MediaElement

segment.source: Web content within a **WebView** control is not directly rendered by the XAML framework and it requires extra work to be composed with the rest of the scene.
segment.target: Web content within a **WebView** control is not directly rendered by the XAML framework and it requires extra work to be composed with the rest of the scene.

segment.source: This extra work adds up when animating the control around the screen and can potentially introduce synchronization issues (for example, the HTML content might not move in sync with the rest of the XAML content on the page).
segment.target: This extra work adds up when animating the control around the screen and can potentially introduce synchronization issues (for example, the HTML content might not move in sync with the rest of the XAML content on the page).

segment.source: When you need to animate a WebView control, swap it with a **WebViewBrush** for the duration of the animation.
segment.target: When you need to animate a WebView control, swap it with a **WebViewBrush** for the duration of the animation.

segment.source: Use infinite animations sparingly
segment.target: Use infinite animations sparingly

segment.source: Most animations execute for a specified amount of time, but setting the **Timeline.Duration** property to Forever allows an animation to run indefinitely.
segment.target: Most animations execute for a specified amount of time, but setting the **Timeline.Duration** property to Forever allows an animation to run indefinitely.

segment.source: We recommend minimizing the use of infinite animations because they continually consume CPU resources and can prevent the CPU from going into a low power or idle state, causing it to run out of power more quickly.
segment.target: We recommend minimizing the use of infinite animations because they continually consume CPU resources and can prevent the CPU from going into a low power or idle state, causing it to run out of power more quickly.

segment.source: Adding a handler for **CompositionTarget.Rendering** is similar to running an infinite animation.
segment.target: Adding a handler for **CompositionTarget.Rendering** is similar to running an infinite animation.

segment.source: Normally the UI thread is active only when there is work to do, but adding handler for this event forces it to run every frame.
segment.target: Normally the UI thread is active only when there is work to do, but adding handler for this event forces it to run every frame.

segment.source: Remove the handler when there is no work to be done and reregister it when it’s needed again.
segment.target: Remove the handler when there is no work to be done and reregister it when it’s needed again.

segment.source: Optimize media resources
segment.target: Optimize media resources

segment.source: Audio, video, and images are compelling forms of content that the majority of apps use.
segment.target: Audio, video, and images are compelling forms of content that the majority of apps use.

segment.source: As media capture rates increase and content moves from standard definition to high definition the amount of resources need to store, decode, and play back this content increases.
segment.target: As media capture rates increase and content moves from standard definition to high definition the amount of resources need to store, decode, and play back this content increases.

segment.source: The XAML framework builds on the latest features added to the UWP media engines so apps get these improvements for free.
segment.target: The XAML framework builds on the latest features added to the UWP media engines so apps get these improvements for free.

segment.source: Here we explain some additional tricks that allow you to get the most out media in your UWP app.
segment.target: Here we explain some additional tricks that allow you to get the most out media in your UWP app.

segment.target: Release media streams

segment.source: Media files are some of the most common and expensive resources apps typically use.
segment.target: Media files are some of the most common and expensive resources apps typically use.

segment.source: Because media file resources can greatly increase the size of your app's memory footprint, you must remember to release the handle to media as soon as the app is finished using it.
segment.target: Because media file resources can greatly increase the size of your app's memory footprint, you must remember to release the handle to media as soon as the app is finished using it.

segment.source: For example, if your app working with a **RandomAccessStream** or an **IInputStream** object, be sure to call the close method on the object when your app has finished using it, to release the underlying object.
segment.target: For example, if your app working with a **RandomAccessStream** or an **IInputStream** object, be sure to call the close method on the object when your app has finished using it, to release the underlying object.

segment.source: Improve media scrubbing
segment.target: Improve media scrubbing

segment.source: Scrubbing is always a tough task for media platforms to make really responsive.
segment.target: Scrubbing is always a tough task for media platforms to make really responsive.

segment.source: Generally people accomplish this by changing the value of a Slider.
segment.target: Generally people accomplish this by changing the value of a Slider.

segment.source: Here are a couple tips on how to make this as efficient as possible:
segment.target: Here are a couple tips on how to make this as efficient as possible:

segment.source: Either bind the value of a **Slider** to **MediaElement.Position** or update it based on a timer.
segment.target: Either bind the value of a **Slider** to **MediaElement.Position** or update it based on a timer.

segment.source: Don't do both.
segment.target: Don't do both.

segment.source: If you choose the latter, make sure to use a reasonable update frequency for your timer.
segment.target: If you choose the latter, make sure to use a reasonable update frequency for your timer.

segment.source: The XAML framework only updates MediaElement.Position only every 250 milliseconds during playback.
segment.target: The XAML framework only updates MediaElement.Position only every 250 milliseconds during playback.

segment.source: The size of the step frequency on the Slider must scale with the length of the video.
segment.target: The size of the step frequency on the Slider must scale with the length of the video.

segment.source: Subscribe to the **PointerPressed**, **PointerMoved**, **PointerReleased** events on the slider to set the **MediaElement.PlaybackRate** property to 0 when the user drags the thumb of the slider.
segment.target: Subscribe to the **PointerPressed**, **PointerMoved**, **PointerReleased** events on the slider to set the **MediaElement.PlaybackRate** property to 0 when the user drags the thumb of the slider.

segment.source: In the **PointerReleased** event handler, manually set the media position to the slider position value to achieve optimal thumb snapping while scrubbing.
segment.target: In the **PointerReleased** event handler, manually set the media position to the slider position value to achieve optimal thumb snapping while scrubbing.

segment.source: Match video resolution to device resolution
segment.target: Match video resolution to device resolution

segment.source: Decoding video takes a lot of memory and GPU cycles, so choose a video format close to the resolution it will be displayed at.
segment.target: Decoding video takes a lot of memory and GPU cycles, so choose a video format close to the resolution it will be displayed at.

segment.source: There is no point in using the resources to decode 1080 video if it’s going to get scaled down to a much smaller size.
segment.target: There is no point in using the resources to decode 1080 video if it’s going to get scaled down to a much smaller size.

segment.source: Many apps don’t have the same video encoded at different resolutions; but if it is available, use an encoding that is close to the resolution at which it will be displayed.
segment.target: Many apps don’t have the same video encoded at different resolutions; but if it is available, use an encoding that is close to the resolution at which it will be displayed.

segment.source: Choose recommended formats
segment.target: Choose recommended formats

segment.source: Media format selection can be a sensitive topic and is often driven by business decisions.
segment.target: Media format selection can be a sensitive topic and is often driven by business decisions.

segment.source: From a UWP performance perspective, we recommend H.264 video as the primary video format and AAC and MP3 as the preferred audio formats.
segment.target: From a UWP performance perspective, we recommend H.264 video as the primary video format and AAC and MP3 as the preferred audio formats.

segment.source: For local file playback, MP4 is the preferred file container for video content.
segment.target: For local file playback, MP4 is the preferred file container for video content.

segment.source: H.264 decoding is accelerated through most recent graphics hardware.
segment.target: H.264 decoding is accelerated through most recent graphics hardware.

segment.source: Also, although hardware acceleration for VC-1 decoding is broadly available, for a large set of graphics hardware on the market, the acceleration is limited in many cases to a partial acceleration level (or IDCT level), rather than a full-steam level hardware offload (i.e. VLD mode).
segment.target: Also, although hardware acceleration for VC-1 decoding is broadly available, for a large set of graphics hardware on the market, the acceleration is limited in many cases to a partial acceleration level (or IDCT level), rather than a full-steam level hardware offload (i.e. VLD mode).

segment.source: If you have full control of the video content generation process, you must figure out how to keep a good balance between compression efficiency and GOP structure.
segment.target: If you have full control of the video content generation process, you must figure out how to keep a good balance between compression efficiency and GOP structure.

segment.source: Relatively smaller GOP size with B pictures can increase the performance in seeking or trick modes.
segment.target: Relatively smaller GOP size with B pictures can increase the performance in seeking or trick modes.

segment.source: When including short, low-latency audio effects, for example in games, use WAV files with uncompressed PCM data to reduce processing overhead that is typical for compressed audio formats.
segment.target: When including short, low-latency audio effects, for example in games, use WAV files with uncompressed PCM data to reduce processing overhead that is typical for compressed audio formats.

segment.target: Images are captured at very high resolutions, which can lead to apps using more CPU when decoding the image data and more memory after it’s loaded from disk.

segment.source: But there’s no sense decoding and saving a high-resolution image in memory only to display it smaller than its native size.
segment.target: But there’s no sense decoding and saving a high-resolution image in memory only to display it smaller than its native size.

segment.source: The units for **DecodePixelWidth** and **DecodePixelHeight** are by default physical pixels.
segment.target: The units for **DecodePixelWidth** and **DecodePixelHeight** are by default physical pixels.

segment.source: The **DecodePixelType** property can be used to change this behavior: setting DecodePixelType to Logical results in the decode size automatically accounting for the system’s current scale factor, similar to other XAML content.
segment.target: The **DecodePixelType** property can be used to change this behavior: setting DecodePixelType to Logical results in the decode size automatically accounting for the system’s current scale factor, similar to other XAML content.

segment.source: It would therefore be generally appropriate to set DecodePixelType to Logical if, for instance, you want DecodePixelWidth and DecodePixelHeight to match the Height and Width properties of the Image control the image will be displayed in.
segment.target: It would therefore be generally appropriate to set DecodePixelType to Logical if, for instance, you want DecodePixelWidth and DecodePixelHeight to match the Height and Width properties of the Image control the image will be displayed in.

segment.source: With the default behavior of using physical pixels, you must account for the system’s current scale factor yourself; and you should listen for scale change notifications in case the user changes their display preferences.
segment.target: With the default behavior of using physical pixels, you must account for the system’s current scale factor yourself; and you should listen for scale change notifications in case the user changes their display preferences.

segment.source: If DecodePixelWidth/Height are explicitly set larger than the image will be displayed on-screen then the app will unnecessarily use extra memory—up to 4 bytes per pixel—which quickly becomes expensive for large images.
segment.target: If DecodePixelWidth/Height are explicitly set larger than the image will be displayed on-screen then the app will unnecessarily use extra memory—up to 4 bytes per pixel—which quickly becomes expensive for large images.

segment.source: The image will also be scaled down using bilinear scaling which could cause it to appear blurry for large scale factors.
segment.target: The image will also be scaled down using bilinear scaling which could cause it to appear blurry for large scale factors.

segment.source: If DecodePixelWidth/DecodePixelHeight are explicitly set smaller than the image will be displayed on screen then it will be scaled up and could appear pixelated.
segment.target: If DecodePixelWidth/DecodePixelHeight are explicitly set smaller than the image will be displayed on screen then it will be scaled up and could appear pixelated.

segment.source: In some cases where an appropriate decode size cannot be determined ahead of time, you should defer to XAML’s automatic right-size-decoding which will make a best effort attempt to decode the image at the appropriate size if an explicit DecodePixelWidth/DecodePixelHeight is not specified.
segment.target: In some cases where an appropriate decode size cannot be determined ahead of time, you should defer to XAML’s automatic right-size-decoding which will make a best effort attempt to decode the image at the appropriate size if an explicit DecodePixelWidth/DecodePixelHeight is not specified.

segment.source: You should set an explicit decode size if you know the size of the image content ahead of time.
segment.target: You should set an explicit decode size if you know the size of the image content ahead of time.

segment.source: You should also in conjunction set **DecodePixelType** to Logical if the supplied decode size is relative to other XAML element sizes.
segment.target: You should also in conjunction set **DecodePixelType** to Logical if the supplied decode size is relative to other XAML element sizes.

segment.source: The URI is used to uniquely identify the underlying content, and internally the XAML framework will not download or decode the content multiple times.
segment.target: The URI is used to uniquely identify the underlying content, and internally the XAML framework will not download or decode the content multiple times.

segment.source: Instead, it will use the cached software or hardware resources to display the content multiple times.
